intro: Dianthus caryophyllus subsp. virgatus, commonly known as the sweet William, is a flowering plant characterized by its showy, clustered flowers in shades of red, pink, and white. It belongs to the Caryophyllaceae family and is native to Europe and parts of Asia. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring upright stems and lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers bloom in early summer, producing a fragrant, spicy scent that attracts pollinators. It is often cultivated in gardens for its ornamental value and is relatively easy to grow in well-drained soil.
